titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Catherine Dickey Autograph Collection
titlestmt.author: compiled by Carol King

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 1, 2019 at 08:06

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

langmaterial.language: The collection is primarily in English, with some French.

did.abstract: The collection, compiled by Catherine Colt Dickey (Mrs. Charles D. Dickey), includes autographs of United States presidents, signers of the Declaration of Independence, government officials, military figures, industrialists, educators, explorers, authors, and other well known persons in public life. Autographs appear on various mediums: letters; postcards; photographs; handwritten and printed documents; and small blank cards specifically designed to solely capture signatures.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright is retained by the creator(s) for unpublished works they have authored or otherwise produced. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Catherine Dickey Autograph Collection (MS 1760). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in two parts: Unbound material and bound material. The unbound material is arranged alphabetically by writer's last name. Bound material is listed alphabetically by the cover title of each volume, with contents described in the order in which they were bound.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection, compiled by Catherine Colt Dickey (Mrs. Charles D. Dickey), includes autographs of United States presidents, signers of the Declaration of Independence, government officials, military figures, industrialists, educators, explorers, authors, and other well known persons in public life. Autographs appear on various mediums: letters; postcards; photographs; handwritten and printed documents; and small blank cards specifically designed to solely capture signatures.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Autographs are listed alphabetically be correspondent's name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The majority of the signed correspondence to Catherine Dickey consists of correspondents sending social pleasantries, such as thank you messages and arrangements to meet, whereas the correspondence to persons other than Dickey is often of a more substantive nature. Ephemera kept by Dickey is listed at the end of the inventory of unbound material.

did.unittitle: To Catherine Dickey and/or Charles D. Dickey

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter by Andrews, director of the American Museum of Natural History, forwarded to Catherine Dickey regarding Robert (Bob) Bartlett and the Greenland Expedition. Included is the signature of Bob Bartlett on an autograph card, 1938 April 23.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Martha Berry was the founder of Berry College, Georgia, in 1902.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: S. S. Drury was the rector of St. Stephen's Church, Boston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A former slave, Gaines was a leader in numerous educational and social organizations for the advancement of women.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter to Catherine Dickey includes correspondence of Mark W. Clark to Kenneth Pendar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a letter of introduction for Pershing from unidentified correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A gravure photograph of Roosevelt inscribed to Mrs. Charles Dickey.

did.unittitle: Illegible signature on Commonwealth of Australia letterhead
To persons other than Catherine Dickey
Bryan, George, to Thomas Bradford, Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: George Bryan was a delegate to the Stamp Act Congress.

did.unittitle: Carroll, Charles (of Carrollton) to Robert Barry

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John Chester, a graduate of Yale College in 1766, was a distinguished war hero during the Revolutionary War.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copyright document for Edmund March Blunt's book, "The (American) Coasting Pilot, " the first book of American sailing directions published in the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph card with sketch of Rear Admiral Dahlgrew.

did.unittitle: Dixon, William Hepworth, to unidentified recipient

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dixon, a prolific author, was the editor of Athenaeum and the author of New America .

did.unittitle: Ellery, William, invoice for "horse keeping in public stables"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ellery was a member of the Continental Congress and signer of the Declaration of Independence.

did.unittitle: Garrison, William Lloyd, to William Rathbone, autograph only

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Graham was chief clerk of the State Department (1807-1817).

did.unittitle: Herford, Oliver, signed program for his play Epilogue

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter re General Asboth of Missouri.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Detailed letter re La Fayette's military efforts to aid the United States against British invasions in the spring of 1781.

did.unittitle: Mason, John, to General John Steele

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter regarding the petition of Captain Nathaniel Brewer for a cartel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter of recommendation for Joseph Pipe for the Office of Inspector.

did.unittitle: Powell, J. H., to Mrs. Sellar
Rantoul, R. (Robert), Jr., to Collector of Customs, Philadelphia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter that accompanied list of crew of the Brig Antares .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter signed as Assistant Secretary of the Navy, Washington, to Edward Corning, New York, expressing appreciation that "you have made this early start in the great campaign...".

did.unittitle: Sargent, Winthrop, to D. Appleton Company, request for books
Sears, Joshua, brief note and clipping of obituary
Wilde, Oscar, to Grosvenor Gallery Library

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes are presumably by Catherine Dickey.

did.unittitle: Handwritten notes regarding opening day, presumably of a London naval conference
Handwritten notes regarding the signers of the Declaration of Independence
Handwritten notes regarding World War I
Newspaper clipping from The New York Times regarding the sale of autograph letters and documents
Newspaper clipping, "Argonne Echoes," by Edward S. Van Zile

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes facsimile of an invitation to a naval ball; handdrawn sketch of a ship; and newspaper article on "sea-going" yachts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Volumes are listed alphabetically by the cover title; contents listed as bound. Loose materials found in some albums were added to the list of unbound materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The majority of signed correspondence in the two volumes is between individuals other than Dickey. Only a small number of items are addressed to Dickey family members.

did.unittitle: "Autographs of the American, British, French, Japanese and Belgian Delegates to the Disarmament Conference Assembled at the Request Of President Warren G. Harding in Washington November 11th (Armistice Day) 1921"
"Autographs of the Presidents of the United States 1789-1925"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first autograph is that of Samuel Francis Smith, patriotic song writer; the remainder are presidential autographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten lyrics of "America," aka "My Country 'Tis of Thee."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter signed, folio, Head Quarters, Middle Brook [New Jersey], to Thomas Burke, delegate to the Continental Congress from North Carolina, relating to the sending of troops to the southern states.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed (with integral address leaf), Auteuil, to Charles William Frederic Dumas at The Hague regarding the "Dutch Nation" and wishing success in forming a "Solid Coalition".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed (with integral address leaf), Philadelphia, to Mr. Church, United States Consul at Lisbon confirming Church's appointment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph note signed to an unnamed recipient expressing regret that the writer's query arrived too late to consult the necessary persons.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, Washington, to Thomas Swan congratulating him on his appointment as a commissioner to settle the Yazoo claims.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, Washington, to William Whiting of Roxbury, Massachusetts, regarding Congressional action on pensions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, Hermitage, to Mrs. Miriam Ayres concerning his attention to business and court records which she asked him to investigate on her behalf.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, oblong, no place, to his brother regarding a real estate transaction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, Head Quarters, Franklin, to John H. Pratt regarding the securing of supplies and drivers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed to Mr. Webster enclosing some letters relating to the Princess Metternich and others which he wants returned.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, as President, Washington, to Secretary of the Treasury Robert J. Walker asking Walker to see "an old lady who will hand you this note" and who is "in great distress".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, Louisville, Kentucky, to Colonel R. Jones discussing methods of securing recruits.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed (marked private), Buffalo, to ...Pruyn? declining an invitation to attend the opening of a railway to Brantford and an evening ball.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed as President, Washington, with autograph envelope, to Postmaster General James Campbell introducing Judge T. O. Wilson of Dubuque, Iowa, who has helpful information on the mails.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph note signed, as President (with wax seal), Washington, to John I McConn? sending his autograph for the writer's son.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A clemency order signed, as President, Executive Mansion, Washington, to Major General George G. Meade, Army of the Potomac, to suspend the execution of Benjamin Van Horn, of First Pennsylvania Artillery until further orders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Grant of Clemency signed, as President (with seal), folio, for Samuel Tate of Shelby County, Tennessee, who has voluntarily taken an oath of allegiance to the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed to L. P. Hubbard, secretary of the New England Society of the City of New York expressing regrets that he cannot attend the Society's annual dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, Spiegel Grove, Fremont, Ohio, with autograph envelope, to J. L. Hillard, clerk of Committees, City of Boston, expressing regret that he cannot attend memorial service honoring General Sherman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, Mentor, Ohio, to Honorable Wirt Sikes of Cardiff, Wales, thanking him for sending "English Goblins".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter signed (LS), as President, Executive Mansion, Washington, to William B. Brokaw thanking him for the presentation of the Newburgh Centennial Medal. Autograph signature on engraved White House card.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, Princeton, to J. B. Gilder, New York, discussing the return of proofs with maps and book dedication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, to Senate Chamber, Washington, to Honorable Warren G. Sayre, State Senate, Indianapolis relating to Harrison's Senate activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, House of Representatives, Washington, to T. C. Prince, Canton, Ohio, introducing Price to Captain Wills of the Naval Academy library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, Sagamore Hill, Oyster Bay [New York] to "Dear Sir" indicating that he will be out of town for the summer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, on Supreme Court stationery, Canada, to Abraham Kunkel regarding the size and hanging of a picture.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed to Mr. Williams regarding a meeting in Philadelphia, with a steel-engraved portrait of Wilson signed in pencil .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed oblong, to McMillan & Kayne regarding an order for cards. Broken at fold.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter signed, as President, The White House, Washington, to Earle P. Charlton regarding the Clarke School for the Deaf.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript signed, on "Herbert Hoover" letterhead, regarding the "ever growing appreciation of Abraham Lincoln's character and of his immortal service....".

did.unittitle: "Autographs of the Signers of the Declaration of Independence"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The volume does not contain autographs of all the signers. Engraved portraits of the signers are present, even though there may not be accompanying autographed material.

did.unittitle: Adams, John, facsimile from a painting

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Document signed as governor of Massachusetts, folio, commissioning James Sprout as a major in the State Militia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Document signed, folio, an arrest warrant for Reuben Peasley, New Hampshire.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed to John H. Latrobe asking for a meeting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph endorsement on a petition signed by Charles Cole to the Governor of Maryland, folio, Baltimore.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Document signed as supervisor of the Revenue, Philadelphia, certifying that duties have been paid on a shipment of gin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ship's passport, Newport, Rhode Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Document signed, identure for sale of land in Onedia County, New York, folio.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Item was removed from the album for preservation treatment and rehoused separately.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Document signed on vellum with seal, oblong folio. Proprietary deed of land to Thomas Gilpin, issued by the Supreme Executive Council of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Document signed as Governor of Massachusetts with seal, folio, appointing Jonathan Wild as Justice of the Peace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph note signed, seeking a favor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Document signed as Governor of Massachusetts, with seal, folio, summoning newly elected State Senator Benjamin Goodhue to a convention of senators.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: .Document signed by Harrison and Thomas Meriwether, Council Chamber, certifying that "James Cooley is entitled to the proportion of land allowed a Private of the Continental line for three years of service".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Colonial currency. "Three Shillings," signed by Hart and others, Burlington, New Jersey. Printed by Isaac Collins.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Warrant for arrest of John Stevenson, signed, Charleston, South Carolina.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: United States bank note, signed by Hopkinson as Treasurer of Loans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, Norwich, Connecticut, to Enoch Perkins commissioning him as Notary Public in the Court of Hartford.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, in the third person, Monticello, expressing thanks to Mr. Samuel Benjamin Helbert Judah for the poem of "Odsfreide" ("Odofriede: the Outcast").

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Power of Attorney, signed by John Chambers, New York, and witnessed by Livingston and John Ernest, folio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, with integral address leaf, Richmond, to Mathew Ridley in Baltimore relating to business of mutual interest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fragment of document with good signature. The body of the document is in another hand. .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Receipt, signed, for monies paid in discharge of a mortgage, Dover, [Delaware].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Document, partly printed, signed, no location, swearing that a certificate in the amount of forty dollars is the property of Dickinson College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Summons, partly printed, signed as Justice of the Peace, Woodbury, Connecticut, for a judgement for debt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signature, clipped.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Document signed, Lebanon, Connecticut, power of attorney.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signature, clipped from letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter signed, folio, Head Quarters, Middle Brook, [New Jersey]. to Thomas Burke, delegate to the Continental Congress, relating to the sending of troops to the southern states.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, Monticello, to Lancelot Minor, concerning the sale of land and the matter of book sent for his personal library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed concerning the Canada expedition and Colonel Conway.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, Boston, to Governor George Clinton of New York introducing Captain Turner of Boston who is relocating to New York to establish a fencing and dancing school.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed, Ashland [Kentucky], to J. R. Witherspoon declining an invitation to visit Blount Springs, Alabama, as his visit would be "...attributed to an electioneering purpose".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed to J. R. Witherspoon re appointment of John Brinridge (?).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter signed to John R. Witherspoon reminiscing about college days at Princeton.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signature on Continental currency note of two dollars.

did.unittitle: Pershing, John and Bishop Charles Henry Brent

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signed photograph.
